reviewText:
30 Minute Quickie Impressions:

It's well done.  You can tell they spent a lot of time making it.

It's easy to get surrounded and die. The combat is fast-paced.

It needs another round or two with the spell checker.

It's currently $1.79. That's a large order of fries. Go for it. You don't need those fries anyway.

reviewText:
ENG:
After playing a little bit in this game, I can say: this game is gorgeous!
Pros of the game:
1) Very interesting story about a prisoner, whom we will play.
2) Good fighting game system, not like in other games of this genre
3) Very nice graphics and textures
4) Courage (imho) soundtrack, which you want to hear and listen to (and you want kick ♥♥♥ when listen this music - check 1st achewement hahaha)
5) Very cheap price, and how many hours you spend it! (Even now there is a discount of 40%) and for the trading card you will be able to pay back part of the price. Also there are achievements.
6) Easy saving + SteamCloud

Of the minuses I can say that there are some minor bugs and problems with resolution and I cant make a screenshot - game is starting from beginning. I recommend to buy the game and support the developer. And all their problems or ideas please write directly to his mail or steam discussions, he will answer for all. (Because he's a good person and open to dialogue)

P.S. Dialogs in game contain hard words, so be carefull if you play with children

RU:
После того, как я поиграла немного в эту игру, я могу сказать: эта игра великолепна!
Плюсы игры:
1) Очень интересный рассказ об узнике, за которого мы будем играть.
2) Хорошая система боя, не такая, как в других играх этого жанра
3) Очень красивая графика и текстуры (для RPG Maker)
4) Заводной (имхо) саундтрек, который вы хотите слышать и слушать (а еще хочется наподдать под зад кому нибудь под эту музыку - смотрите 1-ое достижение хахаха)
5) Очень небольшая цена, зато сколько часов вы проведете в  ней! (Даже сейчас есть скидка в размере 40%), а также вы сможете погасить часть цены коллекционными карточками. Кроме того, есть достижения.
6) Простая система сохранений + облачное сохранение
Из минусов могу сказать, что есть некоторые незначительные ошибки и проблемы, связанные с разрешением и я не могу сделать скриншот - игра начинается с начала. Я рекомендую покупать игру и поддержать разработчика. Обо всех проблемах или идеях, пожалуйста, пишите прямо на его почту или в обсуждениях стим, он ответит на все. (Потому что он хороший человек и открыт для диалога)
P.S. Диалоги в игре содержат жесткие слова (англ), так что будьте осторожны, если вы играете с детьми

reviewText:
My favorite genre of game, the rpg, I remember fondly my first rpg, the amazing Final Fantasy 7, Cloud and his merry band of terrorist (yes they were terrorist, but back when the game first released terrorist meant something totally different than it does today)  I still recall being amazed, the graphics, the sounds, the mini games, I couldn't play the game enough, I put well over 100 hours into FF7, and that was my first save.. other amazing games the suikoden series, who could forget Breath of Fire 3, even Shadow Madness (called one of the first American RPG's by Game informer....  whatever that meant)  So what do Final Fantasy 7  and these other amazing games have to do with Throne - Death Merchants.. not a single thing, except they are both members of my favorite genre and they are all amazing games..

Well then, shall we move on with my review of Thorne - Death Merchants?  Aside from the main character being named Crow, and the name of the fort, nothing else was related to Game of Thrones, so I removed this section

The Story

The story starts you off as Crow, a man shackled in a keeps dungeon.  He's bloody and retelling the tale of a murder!!!  Did Crow commit the murder, was he framed?  Did the butcher, the baker or the candlestick maker frame him???  That is what we'll get to see first hand as you relive the story that Crow tells to his jailer.  I'll expand upon the story as I move through the game...

The Gameplay

The game play is different from many of the other rpgmaker games out there..  it's made using real-time combat as opposed to turn based combat.  I certainly don't mind the real-time combat, It felt out of place for a game using this type of engine, although I did quickly adapt to it, and quickly grew accustomed to it.  After nearly an hour of game play I have to say real-time combat had me more immersed in the game, it felt more interactive, rather than just snoozing through battles pressing the attack button, I was more apt to pay attention during combat, and the combat had an air of difficulty other games made with the same engine don't have.

All the normal rpg options are there, items, equipment, quest, status, the game had an added selection called encyclopedia, this section gives you a brief description of the enemies and NPC's' you're met throughout the game.  (handy addition and helps with immersion).  Another difference between Thorne and other games, is armor, you don't equip armor in the game, instead you equip accessories, which increase your stats, you can equip 4 different accessories.  Another really useful option is the auto loot, no more toiling away checking every barrel/crate/pot/bookshelf.  The items are automatically looted by using sprint, can make finding all the hidden items fairly simplistic.

A few tips to keep in mind...   if the game starts in a tiny window, use alt + enter to bring the game into full screen mode.

Some useful default button's if you're a controller user (xbox 360 wired)  You can remap the buttons but these are the default selections
Y is the attack button,
A is the run button
B brings up your main menu
X is used for interacting with people, and options in your menu.
LB is used for range attacks
RB is used for switching which ranged attack to use
Backspace/select  is used to heal

Pro's
Fun and interactive combat,
Start to a great story
contoller support (yeah i'm that guy, who loves playing his rpg's with a controller)
Auto loot ++++
Music is pleasant
The game is fairly difficult, and requires more than just looking away and choosing the attack option

Con's
Lots of grammar and spelling mistakes (I suck at teh (intentional) spelling and grammer, but I'm not selling a product)

Unresponsive controls are the bane of this game existence.  Action rpg's are fine, but the combat needs to be adjusted to allow far more fluid attacks, and magic.. no reason exist why I should be full MP, press the button and have no magic come, no reason exist why I should press the sword attack button 5 or 6 times before my character eventually attacks..


The Verdict
So the meat and potatoes of any review is the verdict, was the game worth playing, and if it was worth playing would I recommend it for other gamers...  The short answer is absolutely....

The long answer is....  ABSOLUTELY!!!! if you aren't into THESE types of rpg's, then odds are the charm and quaintness will be totally lost on you.  If you have a natural bias against RPG maker or old school games you'll most likely not enough this game at all... (but hey it's cheap and has cards so maybe even you can find a use for it.)  For those who appreciate a well told story (albeit with some spelling and grammar issues) you'll do well to pick this up.  It certainly won't have 50 hours of gameplay, but for 3 dollars what do you expect.  You'll play it, you'll love it, and you'll be wanting the developer to finish up the story (This seems to be an episodic game where you'll get a part of the story now, and then after development is finished have the option of buying??? (not sure) additional episodes to finish out the story)

The game took me a little over 2 hours to complete, the developer is planning on making this an 8 part game, thus far the game has a pretty good foundation on which to build.

reviewText:
I loved to play RPG Maker games, especially those that has good storylines and that have some unique features that is different from the run-of-the-mill type games.

Well, I had a wonderful time with this game, Thorne.
The game mechanics is very unique, as we do not have he regular leveling, or armors, etc.
What it has is a single weapons, and a number of different accessories slots.
So, it is quite refreshing.
The fighting itself is also different as well.
Instead of turn-based, 1-action-per-turn combat, you actually move your character around to try to avoid being hit, and press the attack button (direct combat or range combat) to try to hit the enemy. So the combat mechanics is slightly different.

Another really interesting thing is the 22 Steam achievements. Although you can finished the main quest in 2-3 hours, I actually spend 10 hours, playing the game 3 times, and trying to figure out all the different achievements. This is because the activation of certain events are not too obvious and trying to figure out how to trigger them is part of the fun of the game. There are also different type of exploration puzzles, hidden items, partial keys, etc, that make the game interesting as well. I loved this game.

The only shortcoming that I can think of for this game is : IT IS TOO SHORT :).
However, as I understand it, this is Part 1 of an 8 part episodic game and that we would be able to carry forward our save game to the next episode.
This is really excellent. Furthermore the price of slightly more than $1 for such a game is defintely worth it!!
I love this game, and would look forward to buying and playing all 8 episodes.
Keep up the good work, developers... and I definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
Thorne - Death Merchants is a very simple game, it plays like most RPG Maker games but instead of having turn based party combat, Thorne’s combat is real-time and very fast paced. It really caught me by surprise, it features some nice changes to the default sprites of RPG Maker and it plays in a very different way when compared to other games made with this engine. It is also worth saying that this is the first part of this series but still, the ending is not abrupt or anything, it leaves room for more events to unfold and the story of this part is done, it doesn’t end in a cliffhanger or anything like that.

Before elaborating on some key aspects of the game, I think it is important to first mention some things that I didn’t enjoy about Thorne. The first one is obviously the lack of voice acting but I guess that for a small indie studio this is somewhat hard to put into a game of this scale. The second complaint I have is the fact that a lot of times, it is not very obvious where doors are located when they are on the sides of the screen. Since you have no 3D view they just look like another corridor or dead end, if you get close enough though you’ll go through that passage and proceed to another room. That said, I did find myself a couple of times looking for a place to go when in fact I just had to run against the wall, so to speak.

Story:You play as Crow, a well known mercenary, and you start your journey in a prison cell being interrogated by a guard. You’re being accused of killing someone in a nearby village and so you are explaining to this guard on how you are not guilty of this crime. This how most of the game takes place, you play as you are telling your story to the guard.

Without spoiling, the overall story is pretty decent. What appears to be just another set of simple jobs for a reputable mercenary such as yourself leads to a series of events and mystery concerning the little village of Hollow Lake. The villagers ask for your help  because the local noble has been ignoring them and locked himself in his mansion, leaving the villagers defenseless. It is up to you to help these people and investigate a series of murders that have been occurring.

Gameplay:The game is pretty simple and therefore there isn’t much you need to know, and what you need to know is explained to you early on. For combat, it plays like an action RPG of sorts, A is your melee attack, S is your ranged ability and Q is heal. When you’re low on HP you can use Rage which gives your attack a little boost but requires you to rest at the inn in order to be able to use it again. The game offers atleast 2 different ranged abilities, daggers and molotovs.

The game doesn’t hold your hand, you can go after the main quest if you choose to do so or you can just go on different paths and explore the world. The game rewards exploration because while exploring you can find different kinds of loot. Even though the game has a lot of items for you to find that either heal you or cure certain ailments, I never found myself using any of these because there was simply no need. Sometimes, when you kill an enemy, they will drop loot bags but you can also acquire loot merely by walking through the levels, some spots might have something hidden.

The game has its own menu where you can check your different stats, equip or use items, check your quests, the usual. Still, while the game has various different stats for your character such as strength and agility, the game doesn’t tell you what these do and how they affect your gameplay.

Overall thoughtst:The game features a small but nice soundtrack and the writing is fairly decent even though there’s ocasionally some spelling errors in the dialogue. Combat is serviceable along with level design. Still, for me the story makes up for all the less good aspects of the game. In the end Thorne - Death Merchants is pretty good for its price and I’m looking forward for the next parts of this series.

reviewText:
Product received for free

If you enjoy RPGs -especially those made with RPG Maker- but want something a bit grittier, then Thorne - Death Merchants may be the title to satisfy your cravings. It tells the story of the aforementioned Thorne, also known as the Crow, a mercenary that leaves a trail of dead bodies behind him. Travel through a corrupt world as you meet new people and collect bounties. A fair warning, this game contains quite a bit of vulgar language so some may find it offensive.

Thorne has been taken prisoner for a murder he did not commit and most of the game is spent in a flashback as he explains his story to the captain of the guard. The story, and therefore the game, is rather short. Most of it takes place in one village where the murder you’ve been accused of takes place.When Thorne first arrived he only wanted to drink at the tavern but soon found himself knee deep in the village’s problems as he accepts mercenary jobs from the people. The story that unfolds is rather interesting and becomes more complicated than Thorne anticipated. To go further would spoil things but do expect witches, werewolves, corrupt leaders, beautiful women and evil specters.

The controls of the game pretty simple, you can use your mouse and keyboard to move and attack enemies or you can use a game controller. I found it easier to use a controller but certain things didn’t quite work right. The game gives you no indication of which buttons match which actions, unlike if you use a mouse and keyboard. I never figured out how to use the rage attack with the controller. If the cursor of your mouse is hovering over something it will keep that thing highlighted no matter what you try to select with the controller. That being said, I still appreciated being able to use a controller as I prefer them for RPGs. The user interface isn’t very fancy, a common occurrence in many RPG Maker titles, but it works.

Thorne has a basic sword attack, a ranged attack, and a desperation rage move he can use when his health is low. He can also heal himself. Unlike with many games of the genre, battles are not turn based, but real time. Enemies walk around the screen and will engage you if they see you. This will either turn some people off or please some people, either way it is nice to see something different even if it wasn’t my cup of tea. You have the ability to change your gear to fit your play style, however there aren’t many options due to the length of the game and you can get by pretty ok with just using the optimized gear choices. I also found money in the game to be a bit useless since you find plenty of items during your quest, most of which I rarely used, but if you find yourself in a pinch then stock up. You have no other party members which is a shame but makes sense in the story, however you can acquire a wolf companion to aid you in finding treasure. I never used this feature at all but it is needed to acquire certain achievements.

The artwork in the game is dark and gloomy, fitting the tone of the story. Everything is done in a retro pixel style with well drawn portraits for important characters. There are no cutscenes and the only piece of full artwork is the main title screen which shows Thorne in chains. I did have a bit of an issue with lighting in the game when night fell. I know it’s supposed to be dark at night time but it make it hard for me to see what I was doing and where I was going. The music is in the game is fitting, nothing too amazing but also nothing too annoying either. Everything is in a good balance and nothing seems out of place.

As mentioned earlier, this game is very short and can be completed in two or three hours, maybe four if you’re on the hunt for all of the achievements. My biggest issue with the game was lack of directions. You don’t get a map until near the end of the game and unless you look in every nook and cranny and talk to everyone you possibly can then you’ll miss side quests, and even then some things are time sensitive, which was not indicated in-game. The game has Steam achievements and trading cards and the developers seem to working on new updates and listening to the community. It would see that more episodes of the story are coming in the future which will hopefully flesh the story out more, as of now the price isn’t too bad for the length of the game and it’s a nice change from a lot of the RPG Maker titles currently on the market.


Lunar Productions[lunarproductions.tumblr.com]

reviewText: I thought the game was a lot like Fated Souls in the way the bad guy Thorne was similar to Gauly both being mercenaries and not as rotten as made out to be. In itself the game is quite good but does have problems in lagging especially when playing on Windows XP. To me the game is made more for the use of a game controller than the keyboard and I do not like using keys for the battle system. Leveling up does not seem to do much and the use of points for skill ability is alright, though there are not many skills to use. The game could do with more refinement. I do like the quest inventory as this does help along the way.The actual graphics and scenery are well done. It is very typical of older style RPG's and would be enjoyable to players who like the older style. A dark type of game but overall a good game and I wouild recommend it.

reviewText:
IntroductionThorne - Death Merchants is a RPG maker game, which has done exceptionally well to make it their own and not another generic RPG Mkaer game with slight changes to the default tilsets. That and also the incredibly unique fighting mechanics that I haven't seen other RPG Maker games have.

GameplayThis game has a fairly good and interesting story line to the game, it has some unique features to the game that differentiate it from the generic run of RPG Maker games. Let's start off with the basic of wat the story is behind this game. You start off as a Crow, a man who has been framed and is now trapped in a dungeon shackled up. The story retells what actually happened, full of blood shed of a murder that you didn't commit. But who framed him? The story expands as you play through the game and find out what really happened that night the murder happened. The game has some really unique mechanics to fighting and looting that other games like this don't even touch on. The fighting mechanic isn't your standard turn-based random RPG battles. It plays more like a action game, you can weild certian weapons, are able to throw certain weapons and have to kill enemies in real time. No turn based combat here. There is automatic looting when you push against say a box and it has loot, it'll automatically give you the items that where in that box therefore not really wasting time by having to click a few speech boxes saying what each item is. This really puts a new spin on RPG Maker games, and really sets the game higher bar and shows that you can make really great games with RPG Maker. Athough the game is rather unique, it does have it's unfortunate cons as well. The game does eem rather short, I completed the game in just over 2 hours. Apparently this game is going to have more parts to it, so that's not all that bad. Here's hoping the other parts will be as good as this one.

Pros+ Very unique mechanics
+ Very interesting story-line
+ Decent for the asking price
+ Trading Cards & Achievements

Cons- A little too short, but apparently there are more parts to this series

Result / Final thoughtsThis is a very unique and well thought out RPG Maker game. It's not another generic RPG Maker game, it really makes the game it's own and does it very well. Interesting new mechanics and fighting system that takes a new turn on these types of games. Very interesting story and well thought out level design.

Rating 9.5/10

For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow Good Games Giveaways & Reviews curator group here.

reviewText:
I recommend it to any RPG fan out there.

Nice old-school graphics, cool lighting effects. Art is extremely good.

Story is well paced and interesting. Thorne seems like a very promising character.

Combat is fast paced, there are challenging battles and the customization is quite good. A lot of accessories to choose from. So far only 4 skills though.

Some hidden content to be found, which adds to the exploration.

The game's strenght lies in the story and the characters, specially Thorne, looking foward for his next adventures.
Overall it's very good for what it is, an old-school Action RPG. For the price I say it's an excellent purchase.

reviewText:
- I'm not a big fan of action RPGs, but the combat system is very well done. It's fast-paced, and since the HP and skills are renewed outside of combat, it's also very enjoyable. The game doesn't force you to backtrack or replenish at all.

- The story (and the hero) is well writen, and the overall atmosphere feels quite dark. I also like the way the side-quest are implemented, all of them I've seen so far felt like natural part of the story and game seting.

- The puzzles are quite hard, often I needed to think carefully. There is also a secret stuff there and there.

Overal, I felt Thorne is a big step-up in quality, compared to the previous Warfare games. It's obvious a lot of effort went into it.

reviewText:
I got this key from the developer in exchange for a review. This however does not sway my opinion.

+ Interesting world, combined with wonderful maps
+ Nice soundtrack
+ Cheap
+ Nameable Pet wolf
+ Achievements are easily attainable
+/- Battles aren’t too hard
- Slow transitions and typos
- Missable optional cutscenes
- Missable items

Thorne – Death Merchants is a short game (2~4 hours), the first of a series of eight standalone episodic games. It’s a well-made game by experienced developers that is also being sold quite cheap! It features an interesting world with lovely looking environments and gray characters everywhere. The soundtrack is great and fits the game well. The game also allows you to have a pet wolf, whom you can name, pet, feed and command to search around for treasures. This was a pretty neat idea, though my wolf got stuck from time to time and it took me a while to realize I needed to let the wolf follow me, instead of using the whistle to call it to me. While the treasure hunting idea was fun, I didn’t really get into money or health trouble, so it was moot most of the time. In fact, if it wasn’t because of the achievements I wouldn’t have searched around at all. For the achievement hunters, this game has 22 easily enough attainable ones. Some of them are linked to optional and time-sensitive cutscenes, side-quests, treasure hunting, so you might miss a few of them at the end of the game.

I’m not a ARPG fan or even someone with a lot of experience playing these type of games, and while I died several times playing this game, I do have to say the battles aren’t that hard, with the exception of one or two. It helps that there aren’t that many skills: there’s heal, ranged and close melee and that’s it. I enjoyed the battle system and enjoyed that unless you Leroy Jenkins it, you won’t die. Perhaps others will find this too easy, but I found it just right.

The game does have flaws, however. There’s the slow transitions between areas and the typos in the English game. While they annoyed me a bit, they weren’t detriment to my overall enjoyment of TDM. (The developer is also aware of these and has promised fixes.) What irked me more was how easy you could miss optional cutscenes, as well as items. I had trouble defeating the Abyss Mermaid, until I learned I was actually missing an item, needed to defeat her. Near the end of the game I still hadn’t found it; apparently I had walked past the location of it.  I don’t mind the system this game used for finding items, in fact I actually liked it. However, I feel that sparkling indications for the item in question would have been better. As for the missable cutscenes, I actually did miss one and so the reveal after the final boss battle came out of nowhere for me. To be fair, the story still made sense, but I’m a sucker for story and world/character building scenes.

To conclude, Thorne – Death Merchants was a nice intro to its series, leaving me anxiously looking forward to the next.

reviewText:
Thorne - Death Merchants is a classic 2D style RPG. With a more adult theme than most. Which can be seen in the games text script.
Battles are in realtime. Attack with your sword or ranged weapons. Quick abilities Heal for insta heal and Rage for a stats boost when under 35% health. Q and E keys used for quick casting.
Equipe gear and use items. Or Buy and sell them at stores.
Quests to complete, sleeping at inns to heal, witches and monsters. It has everything a good RPG should have.
Smooth gameplay.

reviewText:
Thorne - Death Merchants is an action RPG based on the RPGMaker engine, and the very beginning was quite a shock to me, based on the language and innuendo being used.  I was surprised, but I will make note that this is a mature type of game.  It's more along the lines of something like Secret of Mana in terms of the style of action RPG gameplay.

Anyway, you start as a captured prisoner, and you begin to tell your story of why you are not responsible for the current crime they are holding you for, and the parts where you are moving about and interacting with things are the flashbacks from the past as you tell the story to the officer in the place where you are being held.

It's not too terribly long, and can be finished in one day or so, depending on how long one would want to play for.  The price of the game makes it much more appealing for the content.  I think it's definitely a reasonable buy.  Here are my basic impressions and overall ideas on the game itself:


Pros
Interesting dialogue with the more mature word choices in many parts.  It's different and was unexpected, so I really like it in a refreshing sort of way, though it is a bit overdone.

The wolf you get is great, although I cannot always find him.  I enjoy the whole process, but I'm not too sure if doing things besides searching raises any sort of affinity or affection or whatever you'd call it.  It's not super important, but I thought it was fun searching for items if I was letting my magic or health raise.

You can either attack on the screen, or damage with projectiles for a distance attack.  The meter gradually decreases as the battle goes on, so you cannot spam the distance attacks.  It's still a great addition to the regular attacks.

Most of the music is not very invasive, and doesn't seem to bother me at all.

Bordering is done well on this one.  I haven't found many areas where I can go beyond the edging.  There are some blocks of empty space that I cannot walk through, but most borders are solid.

For its length, the developers made the pricing very reasonable.  Often I see games that are much too expensive for the length of time they take to finish.  I'm not really sure what all I missed, but I did not even pick up every achievement on my initial run from start to finish.


Cons
No real directions on where to go for the quests.  I was unsure which way was the right way for a lot of the quests.

No map of any sort, either early on.  I like to be able to tell where I am in relation to what is around me. There is a map you get from a treasure chest a bit later on, but it only shows some general regional areas, and isn't a whole lot of help.

Wolf won't always appear where you want it to, so it can take several tries to get it near you when searching.

Clunky stairs.  You can't move diagonally with some sets, and have to move up then left or right, and you sort of get stuck as you're moving along.

Some grammatical errors, which is understandable, but nothing too difficult to understand or anything.


Other Thoughts
The story itself is a strange one, with a bunch of twists and turns.  There is a lot of cursing throughout, which I found kind of interesting for this style of game.  I'm not really used to it, honestly.  Overall though, it worked for the story.  It did seem overdone in some parts though.

It's not incredibly long of a story, and there are not a whole lot of quests.  You'll probably not level up very much either.  It took me a few minutes to find out if I had points to level up with, and how exactly to go about it.

The battles are not very difficult, and you can heal a good bit, plus use items if necessary.  It is possible to pull a few enemies out of a group and kite them a bit until they die, while you wait it out to regain health and magic (which is used for your distance items).

You can sort of escape from battle when you get far enough away from anything attacking you and regenerate your health, then go back to the area to finish off any enemies by using this sort of method, though.

All in all the game sort of ends abruptly in a way, though I was kind of feeling it wrapping up.  Hard to know for sure with RPGs as some are very long.  This one would have been nice going a bit longer, but it's understandable after finishing things up why it ended where it did.

I thought it was interesting, and very different than the usual kind of RPG I've played.  I thought the story was rather interesting, though I wish there was a little more.  Still I'd definitely recommend this game for anyone looking for something that is fairly short and not too tough to play, overall.  Not too tough to get used to playing, and entertaining overall.  The grammar could have been edited a bit more, but I could still understand the idea behind what was being said.  My overall impressions though were that this was a good game, and I'm glad I got to play this!  Definitely worth a try in my personal opinion.

** Disclaimer:  I was given a key to review the game.  This had no impact on my rating**

reviewText:
Thorne - Death Merchants is an action RPG based on the RPGMaker engine, and the very beginning was quite a shock to me, based on the language and innuendo being used.  I was surprised, but I will make note that this is a mature type of game.  It's more along the lines of something like Secret of Mana in terms of the style of action RPG gameplay.

Anyway, you start as a captured prisoner, and you begin to tell your story of why you are not responsible for the current crime they are holding you for, and the parts where you are moving about and interacting with things are the flashbacks from the past as you tell the story to the officer in the place where you are being held.

It's not too terribly long, and can be finished in one day or so, depending on how long one would want to play for.  The price of the game makes it much more appealing for the content.  I think it's definitely a reasonable buy.  Here are my basic impressions and overall ideas on the game itself:


Pros
Interesting dialogue with the more mature word choices in many parts.  It's different and was unexpected, so I really like it in a refreshing sort of way, though it is a bit overdone.

The wolf you get is great, although I cannot always find him.  I enjoy the whole process, but I'm not too sure if doing things besides searching raises any sort of affinity or affection or whatever you'd call it.  It's not super important, but I thought it was fun searching for items if I was letting my magic or health raise.

Bordering is done well on this one.  I haven't found many areas where I can go beyond the edging.  There are some blocks of empty space that I cannot walk through, but most borders are solid.

For its length, the developers made the pricing very reasonable.  Often I see games that are much too expensive for the length of time they take to finish.  I'm not really sure what all I missed, but I did not even pick up every achievement on my initial run from start to finish.


Cons

No map of any sort, either early on.  I like to be able to tell where I am in relation to what is around me. There is a map you get from a treasure chest a bit later on, but it only shows some general regional areas, and isn't a whole lot of help.

Wolf won't always appear where you want it to, so it can take several tries to get it near you when searching.

Clunky stairs.  You can't move diagonally with some sets, and have to move up then left or right, and you sort of get stuck as you're moving along.

Some grammatical errors, which is understandable, but nothing too difficult to understand or anything.


Other Thoughts
The story itself is a strange one, with a bunch of twists and turns.  There is a lot of cursing throughout, which I found kind of interesting for this style of game.  I'm not really used to it, honestly.  Overall though, it worked for the story.  It did seem overdone in some parts though.

It's not incredibly long of a story, and there are not a whole lot of quests.  You'll probably not level up very much either.  It took me a few minutes to find out if I had points to level up with, and how exactly to go about it.

The battles are not very difficult, and you can heal a good bit, plus use items if necessary.  It is possible to pull a few enemies out of a group and kite them a bit until they die, while you wait it out to regain health and magic (which is used for your distance items).

You can sort of escape from battle when you get far enough away from anything attacking you and regenerate your health, then go back to the area to finish off any enemies by using this sort of method, though.

All in all the game sort of ends abruptly in a way, though I was kind of feeling it wrapping up.  Hard to know for sure with RPGs as some are very long.  This one would have been nice going a bit longer, but it's understandable after finishing things up why it ended where it did.

I thought it was interesting, and very different than the usual kind of RPG I've played.  I thought the story was rather interesting, though I wish there was a little more.  Still I'd definitely recommend this game for anyone looking for something that is fairly short and not too tough to play, overall.  Not too tough to get used to playing, and entertaining overall.  The grammar could have been edited a bit more, but I could still understand the idea behind what was being said.  My overall impressions though were that this was a good game, and I'm glad I got to play this!  Definitely worth a try in my personal opinion.

reviewText:
Okay, that was it? that was my thought when i finished it.

It is by no means a bad game, just not very great. Feels quite generic, that being said it's quite cheap and for a game of this type it is very well polished, and at the end of the day engaging enough to play through to the end. But i was surprised by the story being all it was which was a bit generic sadly, and i know this is probabaly partially the fault of the translation, but it comes of as quite cringe worthy at certain key moments.

I thought towards the end of the story it had some potential to pick up and become interesting and spark curiosity but then it ends. Not surprised, nor am i annoyed it was okay, but ultimately underwhelmed.

6.5/10, i still recommend it for the price, at the end of the day i still had some fun.

reviewText:
Thorne - Death Merchants

Rating - 8/10

The guys over at Aldorlea Games were kind enough to give me a key and so I am writing a review for it.
I am a dedicated streamer over on Beam.pro and I streamed this game for my viewers and the response was fantastic.

This game is a very well done RPG. The graphics and the art are top notch. And the story line is a very well rounded one.

However I do have some minor complaints, but I will list them momentarily. This game is a very refreshing game because it  is different. It reminds me of childhood and it has a very nostalgic feel to it.

And it's only 1.79? You can't go wrong with that!!

Pros:
Great art
Great story
Quests are detailed
Characters have personalities
Overall great game!

Cons:
No way to maximize window
I would prefer to use WASD to move instead of click and hold


Other than those to minor complaints, I love this game and I reccomend it to anyone who is an RPG fan! Pick it up now, it's a steal for this price!
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Thorne - Death Merchants is a game that really stands out amongst most other RPG Maker games on Steam. You can see that some real effort and thought went into character design and a coherent world that reminds me of a grim fantasy setting in the style of The Witcher. Instead of the usual turn-based combat, Thorne features real-time combat that is really neatly implemented within the limits of the engine. Albeit the english translation is a bit clumsy at times (could definitely need a language assistant), Thorne introduces some really interesting characters that make me curious for future episodes. Also, the developer listens to feedback and keeps updating and improving the game, which definitely is a plus.

reviewText:
Okay, full disclosure, I sort of helped a little with this game, some light mapping and such. However, it was so little help and so long ago, that I actually forgot about this game for a while. I had to be told that I mapped some parts of it, and I still don't remember doing it. But, that's my life.

Also, I played this on  a crappy borrowed laptop, so there was a lot of lag on the larger maps, and I didn't hear any music or soundtrack. Sound effects were fine, just no music. Again, crappy borrowed laptop, so I don't know if anyone else will have that problem. And due to the lag, I simply wasn't able to play very far into it, just up to the lighthouse part, so this will not be a complete review, simply my first impressions of it.

Anyway, Thorne - Death Merchants is the story of Thorne, a cynical and foul-mouthed mercenary, told in media res to his jailer for crimes yet to be revealed, as he begrudgingly helps the residents of a town under great turmoil.  It seems that the local governor of the town has lost his wee little mind and gone on a bit of a killing spree, so Thorne agrees to hunt the psycho down and deal him some Charles Bronson-style street justice. But, being an RPG, things are never that simple, and Thorne gets pulled into something bigger than simple hired vigilantism.

The game itself looks very good, even for an RM game. The sprites are large and detailed, and the environments are lush and quite nice to look at; the dungeons, rather than being a series of narrow tunnels, seems to borrow design elements from the //dot.hack" series

reviewText:
Albeit short, this game was fun. The plot is intriguing and the characters are believable. The dialogue is both mature and entertaining. I could definitely see a sequel to expand on the current plot.

The game is a little flawed though:

1) The grammar and spelling could use some polishing.

2) Manipulating the wolf is a rather wonky process, as he tends to get stuck behind obstacles and keep a rather long distance from you; I guess he likes his personal space? It would also be nice if you could point to where you specifically want the wolf to search within a reasonable distance of the main character.

3) You really don't have a need for much of the game's currency (Rowens), as you can often find things to survive by just roaming and defeating enemies, or having the wolf search for things. Might want to improve on that for the sequel.

Some optional interaction with the ladies who take payment for a good time (can't write the W word here lol) could be fun too but that feature would likely offend many players.

On a side note, the rhythm of the Hornhold theme makes me think of Exes and Ohs" by Elle."
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After actually sitting down and playing through this game I definitely have a few gripes...

*PROS*
- Great mapping/atmosphere
- Witcher-like feel

*CONS*
- Really easy to get cornered/obliterated
- No autosave - and no queues to some boss fights
- Chock full of spelling/grammatical errors

The game starts off pretty strong - and it had a lot of potential but it's far too short to deliver a sense of accomplishment. You're basically in this one town and you get a few quests (about ten including side quests) to learn some history of it's residents and the surrounding country...the game just felt like just an introduction - there was no real climax or ending.

EDIT: Was experiencing major lag - but after upgrading to Windows 10 the problem somehow fixed itself, so...
